questions.text:
1. A four-year-old child presents with difficulty in walking, a broad-based gait, and inability to perform heel-to-toe walking. The child was clingy towards his mother. On examination, the child is hyperreflexive, and the Babinski sign is positive. What could be the probable diagnosis?

ADEM- Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of difficulty in walking, a broad-based gait, and inability to perform heel-to-toe walking, hyperreflexive, and positive Babinski sign suggests a clinical diagnosis of Spastic diplegic type of Cerebral palsy. 

Spastic diplegia involves bilateral spasticity of the legs that is greater than in the arms. Spastic diplegia occurs due to the injury to the immature white matter during the vulnerable period of immature oligodendroglia between 20 and 34 weeks of gestation, hence seen in those born prematurely. It is often noted when an affected infant begins to crawl. The child uses the arms normally but tends to drag the legs behind more as a rudder, like a commando-crawl, rather than using the normal four-limbed crawling movement.

Examination of the child reveals symmetric spasticity in the legs with brisk reflexes, ankle clonus, and a bilateral Babinski sign. Walking can get significantly delayed, the feet are held in a position of equinovarus, and the child walks on tiptoes. In older children, a scissoring gait is characterized by the knees and thighs pressed together or crossing each other while walking, caused by high muscle tone (spasticity) in the hip adductors.



The subtypes of cerebral palsy and the pathology involved are given below:

Cerebral palsy subtype Pathology
Spastic diplegia Periventricular leukomalacia
Spastic quadriplegia Multi-cystic encephalomalacia
Spastic hemiplegia Middle cerebral artery territory infarction
Dyskinetic cerebral palsy Basal ganglia


Other options:

Option A: Guillain-Barré syndrome causes acute flaccid paralysis. It generally follows 1-6 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. The clinical features include an acute onset of bilaterally symmetrical ascending weakness without any features suggestive of CNS involvement.  

Option C: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an immune-mediated cerebral inflammation following viral exanthem or vaccination. Patients present with altered consciousness, convulsions and multifocal neurological signs affecting the cerebellum, optic nerves, long tracts and spinal cord. Fever may be absent at the time of onset of the disease.

Option D: Spinal cord lesion leads to clumsy gait, foot deformity, bladder dysfunction, or stunted limb growth.

questions.text: 2. A six-week-old infant presents with failure to thrive and poor feeding. He complains of non-bilious vomiting immediately after feeding, which started three weeks after birth. The vomiting is forceful but not projectile. Bowel movements are normal. Per-abdominal examination has no significant findings. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a six-week-old infant with failure to thrive, poor feeding, non-bilious, forceful, non-projectile vomiting immediately after feeding, normal bowel movements, and no significant findings on per-abdominal examination suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease.

It involves the retrograde movement of gastric contents across the lower oesophageal sphincter into the oesophagus. It is the most common oesophageal disorder in children of all ages and can occur physiologically.

Infantile reflux presents with regurgitation, especially postprandially. Signs of esophagitis, like irritability, arching, choking, gagging, and feeding aversion, can also be seen. All these result in failure to thrive. Symptoms resolve spontaneously in the majority of infants by 12-24 months. Infants may also present with obstructive apnea or stridor or lower airway disease, in which reflux complicates primary airway disease, such as laryngomalacia or bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

Treatment depends on the patient’s age, nature and severity of symptoms. Infants should be burped well, and overfeeding must be avoided. Measures such as thickening of feeds can be adopted as they not only increase the calorie content but also reduce visible regurgitation.

Other options:

Option A: Cow milk protein allergy presents with blood in stools.

Option C: Intestinal obstruction presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.

Option D: Pyloric stenosis usually manifests at around 3 weeks of age as projectile vomiting. The vomitus is non-bilious in nature. Clinically, an olive-shaped, firm, movable, approximately 2 cm in length mass is palpable in the epigastrium. When the infant is given a feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right.

questions.text: 3. A neonate born at 36 weeks of gestation presenting with respiratory distress requires to be on 30% FiO2. He is otherwise normal. A chest X-ray is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the newborn of 36 weeks gestation presenting with respiratory distress on 30% FiO2, and chest X-ray showing fluid in the intralobar fissures suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Transient Tachypnea of the newborn.

It is more common in a term infant. Other risk factors are twin gestation, maternal asthma, maternal hypertension, late prematurity, precipitous delivery, perinatal depression, gestational diabetes, macrosomia, and cesarean delivery, particularly without labour. It occurs due to ineffective clearance of fetal lung fluid, which leads to retained fetal lung fluid, which decreases pulmonary compliance and impedes gas exchange. 

It is characterised by the early onset of tachypnea (>60 breaths/min), and sometimes along with retractions or expiratory grunting. Cyanosis, if present, is relieved by minimal O2 supplementation (<40%). The chest radiograph shows prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the intralobar fissures. Small pleural effusions may be present rarely. Supportive treatment is required, and most of the infants recover rapidly. 

Other options :

Option B: Respiratory distress syndrome occurs primarily in neonates of less than 34 weeks of gestation. The X-ray in such cases shows low lung volumes, a diffuse, fine reticular granularity of the parenchyma (ground-glass appearance), and air bronchograms.

Option C: Meconium aspiration syndrome commonly affects term and post-term babies. Also, the chest X-ray here will show patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of both lung fields, increased anteroposterior diameter, and flattening of the diaphragm with possible pneumothorax. There is usually a history of fetal distress and hypoxia requiring resuscitation at birth, and infants are meconium-stained.

Option D: Pneumonia is seen in term and preterm neonates. The neonate also has features of sepsis in addition to respiratory distress. Chest X-ray shows asymmetric patchy parenchymal opacities.

Pearl PM0028: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

* Mediastinal shift

* Bowel loops in the left hemithorax



 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

* Low lung volume

* Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)

* Air bronchogram

* White-out lung (severe disease)



Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

* Hyperinflation

* Patchy infiltrates

* Coarse streaking

questions.text:
4. A 4-day-old neonate is being breastfed by her mother. Consider the following. Which shows proper attachment?

1. Cheeks and mouth are full

2. More areola is visible below than above its mouth

3. Chin touches mother's breast 

4. Lower lip inverted
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1 and 3. 

Signs of good attachment of the baby’s mouth to the nipple include

* The mouth is wide open

* Most of the nipple and areola are in the mouth, and only the upper areola is visible

* The baby’s chin is touching the mother's breast

* The lower lip everted

Position of the mother:

* The mother can assume any position of comfort. She can sit or lie down.

* She should not lean on her newborn, and her back should be well supported.

Position of the baby:

* Baby’s whole body should be supported, not just the neck or shoulders

* Baby’s head and body are in one line without any twist in the neck

* Baby’s body should be turned towards the mother (the abdomen of the neonate and the mother touching each other)

* Baby’s nose should be at the level of the nipple.

questions.text: 5. A 9-month-old child is unable to sit without support but can roll over from side to side. The child can say words like 'mama' and 'dada' without meaning and exhibits stranger anxiety, becoming distressed upon encountering unfamiliar people. What is the appropriate next step in managing this child's development?

choices.text: Reassurance since it is a normal developmental variant
Immediate referral for assessment of development
Start physical therapy to help her sit

questions.solution:
The appropriate next step in managing this child's development is reassurance, since it is a normal developmental variant.

Normally, the gross motor milestone of sitting without support starts developing from the age of 8 months. The upper limit of age for being able to sit without support is 10 months, and the child is only 9 months old. Hence, the mother must be reassured about the concern.  

Upper limit of age for the attainment of milestones

Milestone Age
Visual fixation or following 2 months
Vocalisation 6 months
Sitting without support 10 months
Standing with assistance 12 months
Hands and knees crawling 14 months
Standing alone 17 months
Walking alone 18 months
Single words 18 months
Imaginative play 3 years


Pearl PM1926: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks




Pearl PM1927: Language milestones

 
Age Milestone
1 month Alerts to sound
2 months Coos (musical vowel sound)
4 months Laughs aloud
6 months Monosyllables sounds (ma, ba)
9 months Bisyllables (mama, baba)
12 months 1-2 words with meaning
18 months 8-10 word vocabulary
2 years 2-3 word sentences (uses pronouns like I, me, you)
3 years Asks questions and knows name and gender
4 years Sings songs, poems and tells stories
5 years Asks meaning of words


Pearl PM0013: Gross motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
3 months Neck holding
5 months Rolls over
6 months Sits with support

Stands without support

Creeps well

Walks but falls
15 months

Walks without support

Creeps upstairs
18 months Runs
2 years Walks upstairs and downstairs (2 feet/step)
3 years

Walks upstairs with alternate foot

Rides tricycle
4 years

Walks downstairs with alternate foot

Hopping on 1 foot
5 years Can skip without falling to either side


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Note:

The attached pearl mentions the developmental milestones according to the Indian scenario. However, there are some minor differences in the age of attainment of milestones as per International guidelines.

A few major milestones, according to the International guidelines are mentioned below

Neck holding- 2 months Sits without support - 6.5 months Rolling over - 7 months Creeping, cruising - 10 months Walking independently- 12 to 15 months

questions.text: 6. Which of the following describes the metabolic status of Marasmus?

choices.text: Edema due to severe protein deficiency
Severe calorie deficit with normal serum protein
Increased insulin levels with reduced lipolysis
Positive Nitrogen balance and low cortisol levels

questions.solution:
Severe calorie deficit with normal serum protein describes the metabolic status of Marasmus.

Marasmus is a severe form of wasting due to starvation or illness. Fat and muscle tissues are consumed to make energy, leading to severe wasting of these tissues. There is a loss of muscle mass due to catabolism and depletion of the somatic protein compartment. This provides the body with amino acids as a source of energy. The visceral protein compartment, which is more critical for survival, is depleted only marginally, so serum albumin levels are either normal or only slightly reduced.

The child appears very thin with marked loss of fat. There is wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks and thighs. The loss of the buccal pad of fat gives an aged or wrinkled appearance, also known as the monkey facies. The loosening of the skin of the buttocks gives a baggy pants appearance. There is no oedema. Children with marasmus appear to be alert in spite of their condition. 

Other options:

Option A: There is no oedema in marasmus. Oedema is seen in kwashiorkor.

Option C: Decreased insulin levels with increased lipolysis are seen in marasmus due to increased usage of the energy stores of the body.

Option D: Negative Nitrogen balance occurs due to increased breakdown of tissues, and high cortisol levels are seen due to chronic starvation.

Pearl PM2450: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign


The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.



 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.



 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: 7. A 2-year-old child presents with leg pain, difficulty walking and easy fatigability. Which is the unusual diagnosis for this?
questions.solution:
The unusual diagnosis for this clinical presentation is Metastatic retinoblastoma.

The given clinical symptom of leg pain signifies that the patient has bone involvement due to a disease. Retinoblastoma spreads by direct extension to the choroid or along the optic nerve to the central nervous system, or by hematogenous or lymphatic spread to distant sites, including bones, bone marrow, and lungs. However, Retinoblastoma rarely presents with metastasis at the time of diagnosis. Evaluation for tumour metastasis using the cerebrospinal fluid, bone marrow, and radionuclide bone scan is required only if indicated by clinical, laboratory, or imaging findings.

Ewing sarcoma, Metastatic renal clear cell sarcoma, and Metastatic neuroblastoma present with bone involvement as a common presentation. 

Other options:

Option A: Ewing sarcoma patients commonly present with pain, swelling, limitation of motion, and tenderness over the involved bone or soft tissue.

Option B: Metastatic renal clear cell sarcoma presents with secondaries to bone. A bone scan to look for bone metastasis is performed as soon as the histologic diagnosis confirms clear cell sarcoma of the kidney or rhabdoid tumour of the kidney. 

Option D: Metastatic neuroblastoma with common sites of metastasis are the regional or distant lymph nodes, long bones and skull, bone marrow, liver, and skin.

questions.text: 8. A neonate presenting with jaundice due to breastfeeding is due to a fatty acid inhibition of ___
questions.solution:
A neonate presenting with jaundice due to breastfeeding is due to a fatty acid inhibition of the Conjugation of bilirubin.

Breast milk jaundice is a type of neonatal jaundice that occurs in neonates due to breast milk. It usually happens within the second to third week of life due to the abnormal accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to jaundice.

Breast milk contains high concentrations of beta-glucuronidase, which deconjugates bilirubin excreted in the intestine after conjugation by the liver. Increased free fatty acids and increased enterohepatic circulation also interfere with bilirubin conjugation.

Breastfeeding should be continued, and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels. Phototherapy may be beneficial in some cases.

questions.text: 9. A mother brings a child, born at home without complications, who shows cyanosis on crying. There was a noticeable systolic murmur. The doctor diagnosed the case as Tetralogy of Fallot. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is seen in Tetralogy of Fallot. 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic heart disease characterised by the classic tetrad of:

* Severe right ventricular outflow obstruction

* Large VSD

* Aorta that overrides the VSD 

* Right ventricular hypertrophy

The blood flows from the right ventricle into the pulmonary artery across the pulmonary stenosis, producing an ejection systolic murmur. The intensity of the systolic murmur is inversely related to the severity of pulmonary stenosis. The more severe the pulmonary stenosis, the bigger the right-to-left shunt, which further leads to increased cyanosis.

The commonest symptoms are dyspnea on exertion and intolerance to exercise. Anoxic spells occur mostly after waking up or following exertion. The child starts crying, becomes dyspneic, and may also lose consciousness. Convulsions can also occur. The frequency varies from once in a few days to several attacks every day. The patients squat as soon as they get dyspneic. Squatting increases venous return to the right side of the heart and also increases systemic vascular resistance, leading to an increased flow through the obstructed right ventricular outflow.

On auscultation, first sound, a single second sound, and an ejection systolic murmur that ends before the audible single second sound can be heard. The electrocardiogram shows right axis deviation with right ventricular hypertrophy. The T waves are usually inverted in right precordial leads, and P pulmonale may be present, but is uncommon. The absence of the main pulmonary artery segment gives it the shape described as Coeur en Sabot or boot-shaped heart. Pulmonary fields are oligemic. The diagnosis is confirmed on electrocardiography.

The image given below shows the cardinal features seen in TOF:



Pearl PM0193: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)



 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)



 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC



 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly



Pearl PM0251: Important radiological signs in cardiology

Sign

Fallot’s tetralogy

Endocardial cushion defects

Ebstein's anomaly
Jug handle appearance
Primary pulmonary artery hypertension
“3” like appearance of the aorta
Coarctation of aorta
Egg-on-string appearance
Transposition of great vessels
Egg in cup appearance, Pericardial calcification
Constrictive pericarditis
Snowman’s heart, Cottage loaf appearance, Figure of Eight appearance
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
Scimitar sign

Atherosclerosis, Syphilis
Hilar dance on fluoroscopy
Atrial septal defect

questions.text: 10. A 14-year-old female with SLE presents with proteinuria and rising creatinine. Renal biopsy shows a wire loop lesion. What is the most appropriate induction therapy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario female with SLE with proteinuria, rising creatinine and renal biopsy showing a wire loop lesion, suggests the diagnosis to be lupus nephritis. The most appropriate induction therapy is Cyclophosphamide + IV steroids.

Corticosteroids form the most important part of the induction therapy. Severe disease is treated with high doses of intravenous methylprednisolone. Corticosteroid dosages are gradually tapered over months as disease manifestations improve.

Cyclophosphamide is a steroid-sparing immunosuppressive agent added to limit cumulative steroid exposure. Cyclophosphamide is used for severe, potentially life-threatening SLE manifestations, such as renal, neurological, and cardiopulmonary disease. It is highly effective in controlling the disease. The potential toxicities include cytopenias, infection, hemorrhagic cystitis, premature gonadal failure, and increased risk of future malignancy.

Other options:

Option A: Rituximab can be used to treat severe haematological manifestations and is not the preferred agent in induction therapy.

Option C: Mycophenolate mofetil can be used in maintenance therapy once the remission has been achieved. Mycophenolate mofetil monotherapy for induction is not recommended. It can be used as an add-on drug, but corticosteroids are the mainstay for induction therapy.

Option D: Only High-dose steroids will not be recommended since additional therapy is required in cases of SLE with renal, neurological, and cardiopulmonary manifestations.

Pearl PM1568: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 


* Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli

* Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli

* Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus

* Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text:
11. Which vaccine is contraindicated in a child with SCID?

SCID- Severe Combined Immunodeficiency
questions.solution:
MMR is contraindicated in a child with SCID.

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) is suggestive of immunocompromised status in the child. The child should not receive the MMR vaccine, as it is a live attenuated vaccine which is contraindicated in immunocompromised people.

Contraindications for live vaccines:

* Immune deficiency diseases

* Suppressed immune responses as a result of 

* Leukaemia

* Lymphoma

* Malignancies

* Corticosteroid therapy

* Treatment with alkylating agents and antimetabolite agents 

* Therapeutic radiation

* Pregnancy

Pearl PM2192: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

*

Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

*

Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

*

Dose: 0.5ml.

*

Route: Subcutaneous.

*

Site: Right arm (usually).

*

Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

*

Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

*

Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

*

Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

*

Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

*

Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

*

Duration of protection: Life long.

*

IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

*

Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.
